text:
I usually enjoy these documentaries, but I was a bit disappointed by this one. It's all good and well showing these beautiful concept structures, but, unless I missed something, there was no mention of safety elements such as what happens during a storm or other extreme weather event? Especially since these will probably be more common due to climate change.

Would the structure bob up and down in a storm causing seasickness? Or could it be dragged away or tipped over by strong wind and waves? What about the ongoing maintenance requirements - is this more difficult/expensive than for a house on land? 

I know this might sound boring, but these are important considerations. The documentary made it seem like these elements had not been thought about.

text: I do not deny the reality of climate change.  It is real and has gone on for as long as this world has had an atmosphere.   The world has warmed and cooled in cycles for as long as it has existed. What i question is whether humanity is really having as large an impact as alarmists say.  I also question whether the measures demanded by the alarmists will do as much as they claim.  From my point of view, it is ridiculous to say that humanity can stop climate change.  Minimize our impact, sure, but to say we can stop it is like saying we can stop the tide. The current warming trend has gone on for more than 10k years.  And they tell us we can stop it?  Yeah right.
author: AnonAMouse

text:
Started off like a great documentary, or maybe I was suddenly paying a bit more attention, but the translations in the narrative make me suspicious when I do happen to understand some of the French being spoken by the architect that lives in the heart of Paris on the river for 4 decades. (How does anyone but the insanely rich pull off building a permanent house on the river? And in the capital city???) Such as when I hear the word "necessity" been translated into "has too" (23:50 iirc), that just makes me suspicious as too what else gets lost in translation... But then I'm listening to wealthy people blaming "society for the damage done to the environment" almost makes me sick too my stomach at this point! 
Personally, i blame the corrupt politicians and the giant monopolies they have enabled and/or enriched themselves from for decades. 
Corporations have shaped society with their filthy psychological manipulations, poisoning the masses with pharmaceuticals and our diets. They control all the economies, the mainstream media outlets, the laws and regulations. 
And even when we wise up to the facts and demand change, the people are still rarely acknowledged by those in power. 
I blame the 1% that have more accumulated wealth than the other 99% of the global population. 
Because id gladly go without the materialistic crap and go back too a less intrusive life. If it meant change, like actual change, not some meaningless targets by some timeframe that most human beings can't properly appreciate, the people who can know they have no horse in the race because they already elderly... 
And then you say its only 2¬∞ knowing most people won't think of that 2¬∞ in the overall climatic sense and think its just added onto the highest temps they get daily during a year. 
Its such gross manipulation, just like the oil corporations have been doing for almost 5 decades!
Oh yeah, and if I didn't have too listen too another douchbag blaming "ourselves" for this climate mess. 
There's only one genuinely wealthy man that doesn't piss in everyones pocket saying it "costs too much to fix this" and just gets on with it. And he runs one of the most successfull car companies at this time, and builds reusable rockets that land upright, among many other projects in the quest of advancing mankind in ways the world will appreciate for as long as it exists. 
Really, how much longer till the masses wake up to the barrage of BS and accept what most peoples commonsense and intelligence are telling them is anyones guess. But if a highschool dropout like myself can see through it, todays Kids will definitely if they don't already. Lets see if they're willing to join the masses in blissful ignorance in helping the wealthy get wealthier from their futures.... 
Sorry for my rant you other 99%, but I was listening to the rest of this somewhat BS doco and it pee'd me right off!

text: The 6 most common elements contained in life are nitrogen, oxygen, carbon. hydrogen, Sulphur, and phosphorus. CO2 contains 2 of those 6 and is essential for a green earth, an atmosphere low in CO2 will cause a slow down in every aspect of biology on earth. CO2 in the atmosphere is a trace gas. The climate models we have been exposed to have all been wrong and the ice that was supposed to be gone by 2013 is still here and in some cases even growing. Carbon credits are an excuse for global taxes to fund a one world government and stifle productivity. Does anyone understand that 3 or 4 hundred parts per million is not at all excessive and is what allows life to thrive. Most science these days is narrative driven consensus when it should  be evidence based debate.

text:
"60 meter sea rise" is a very tall lie. It is all Bull sh..t Everything is fine with Mother Earth and her seven seas because there is NO REAL CLIMATE EMERGENCY, only normal unpredictable weather despite what cruel "child scaring hysterics" say! They are wrong and you can relax about your precious children's future.
Atmospheric CO2 is still too close to starvation-levels at current 400 ppm, so we could be living in a greener and lusher world if it could be boosted to 1,000 ppm again, as in past lush Interglacial periods. Humans are now recycling past plant-material transubstantiated into coal and oil which contribute very little to this huge global CO2 metabolism.

Green plant photosynthesis must be able to eat atmospheric CO2 to fabricate Carbohydrate sustenance and release O2 gas for us to breathe. Gaseous CO2 is for plants like life-giving breathable O2 gas is for us humans and animals. CO2 is NOT a poisonous weather pollutant and instead we depend on green plants and their productive use of CO2 for our survival!

FACT IS that we live at the tail end of a 10,000-year INTERGLACIAL CYCLE and in just another one or two thousand years we are likely to slowly enter a statistically inevitable ~90,000 yearlong ICE-AGE. The seas in Northern Europe are draining due to the LAND-RISING because of the past pressure of a several kilometres thick ice-cap that  once weighted  the Northern land down. In other areas we see a relative SEA-RISING due to land dropping, especially at the edges of the grinding tectonic plates. Our planet is still ALIVE, and we can see this in beautiful geysers and destructive earthquakes and VOLCANIC eruptions. It is Earth as usual and perfectly normal!

That's right, our old Earth have had many such ICE & GREEN CYCLES with each averaging a total of about one hundred thousand years! So, we are extremely lucky to live at the optimum habitual time in current INTER-GLACIAL period, when obviously glaciers and polar caps melt and sea-level goes up. This climatic trend will reverse like a pendulum and the world will again grow massive icecaps that drains much of the seven seas all over again! Sadly, green plants and most living things will slowly perish over the next ice-age's many millenniums. Hopefully, the coming Ice-age will leave us a wide survival "zero-season-zone" around the equator for our future generations to escape to.

Earth's complicated and varied climate reflects so many factors like humidity, reflective cloud cover, Earth rotational tilt angle, the shape of the annual elliptical orbit around the sun and of course interplanetary and interstellar radiation. And most of all, what "mood" our great all mighty shining SUN happens to be in!

We "bipeds" are not as important "weather-masters" as we like to think or fear, and I hope you understand that we definitely cannot "operate" and "control" Earth climate destiny by choosing a nuclear vs. wind electricity providers and driving to shops in a newly manufactured 1830 kg electrically charged (...from?) car instead of keeping the swift old VW or Fiat.  Lunching on vegan or eating genuine human food makes for no change, except for farting-frequency. Ignore slick advertising and enjoy your unique gift of life to the fullest and give the "climate hysterics" the "finger" because they are out to destroy your mental health for absolutely nothing in return. Trust me, we are so blessed to be alive in this time of geo-history!

Finally, the real environmental problems are associated with foolish over-population, over-consumption, over-fishing, rapidly shrinking animal habitats and species eradication. Pollution of seas and air must stop, especially from China and all over Asia. Human-induced "Paleogenic" global climate change is not a problem because it does not even exist, except in wild weather fantasy

After a mass extinction the time it takes for the world to reform, reforest , for animals to be 'created ' and evolve again can take hundreds of millions of years.

But either way, the problems of pollution are real. Scientists studying these problems believe we ALREADY INSIDE a state of mass extinction. In some cases in the past Mass Extinctions happened gradually over thousands of years .Now these pollution changes and the plant/animal die-offs  are happening rapidly.
The governments around the world are only playing lip-service to the pollution problems. Their pollution carbon taxes laws allow any other high polluting business company to buy 'carbon tax credits ' . These credits are issued to businesses which if they use less than the allotted amount allowed , can be sold to other higher polluting business companies for money. If the scientists are right, that we ARE in the middle of a Mass Extinction including humans, then the Earth will continue it's species of life forms until it once again becomes completely barren. People are trying to make changes. Yesterday i put up a video about a man who is changing whole  deserts into green fertile land complete with streams and able to grow crops. 
If / when the Singularity comes - please look it up if you aren't familiar with this advanced technology - - the powers at the top have the idea that the whole world's population will be connected to computers straight through the brain, into ONE singularity - ONE computer - ONE brain - ONE force - One mind -

text:
The problem is that global warming presents a huge number of problems beyond just rising sea levels. We can live in houses on water, but all the problems of global warming will still be present. As it is, so many people are ignoring the science and denying that global warming is happening, or that humans are contributing to it, that we'll create an utter ecological disaster for ourselves. 

I mean, just the basic science of how the cycle of climate change occurs, and the scientific consensus and evidence that shows how humans have badly disrupted that natural cycle (essentially creating in a couple of centuries a rise in CO2 and global temperature that used to take millennia), all of it is just ignored by so many people. 

(How can people buy what their politicians say and ignore the scientists (especially scientific consensus), even when the scientists dumb-down their findings so a little kid could understand?)

If global warming continues to happen so fast, there are a number of things we can count on. The average temperature will rise to the point people can barely live outside - such as temperatures over 50 degrees centigrade. The radical change in climates all over the world will cause wide-spread ecological collapse (the plants and animals we eat would be affected too). Run-away mechanisms would kick in, and one way or the other, the sea currents would become disrupted, and our weather would become far more violent.

But no, denial is better, huh? Why bother trying to minimise the damage?

text:
The first three lines had me concerned. I haven‚Äôt heard such biased reporting for ages. Do some research yourself and you‚Äôll find alternative scientific evidence which means the science is not settled!
It was Goebels who said if you keep reinforcing the same rhetoric over and over people will believe it must be true. Don‚Äôt be a lemming...think for yourself!
Many news media, and other media, have publicly stated they will not publish any evidence that doesn‚Äôt support climate change; That used to be called propaganda!
This is a serious issue that requires proper consideration of all the facts. In history Innocent people have died because of skewed evidence.
People have become so polarised and not prepared to listen to any alternative point of view. Listen to both sides, honestly, then make up your mind.
If you can look yourself in the mirror and tell yourself you‚Äôve honestly looked at both sides of any argument without bias and then come to a conclusion...
then you can follow your convictions with confidence.
author: Richard Abernethy

text:
This documentary totally misses the ball.

Talk about how WE will have to adjust is like talking about how a persons belt may need adjusting.   The concept of ‚Äúadjustable‚Äù is built into the essence of a belt just as adjustability is built in to the essence of a human.    

Climate change is a non factor in the immediate short run for an adjustable species.   

It‚Äôs the non adjustable species in which will be wiped out due to such a rapid change in environmental conditions. 

This documentary would be better if it focused on our relationship to those species.   

We rely on them big time.   

This is the issue at hand.  

The issue is Rapid warming where most species can‚Äôt keep up with the needed level of adjustment and therefore die off and potentially go extinct.

text:
¬†@Annette Washington¬† 
Global warming has been happening for the last 10 or 12 thousand years, since the ending of the last glaciation period, more popularly known as the "ice age". Canada, New York, and northern Europe was under 2 miles of ice.
99% of ice melting and sea level rise occurred before 1800, and continues to this day.
Global warming is not man made.

It is cooler now than most of the last 10,000 years.
The next ice age is just around the corner.
Technically, we are still in an "ice age" that started nearly 3 million years ago.  We are in a warm period within the ice age. It is a roughly 100,000 year cycle, with about 85 to 90 thousand years of glaciation and 10 to 15 thousand years of warming.
Global warming is not man made.  It occurs and repeats roughly every 100,000 years.

text:
¬†@Bozza¬† 
Actually, humans are saving the planet by restoring CO2 to the atmosphere, which is causing Global Greening.  CO2 is plant food, which has been depleted over hundreds of millions of years.  More CO2 and more warmth is great for the preservation and expansion of plant life. 

If man hadn't come along to restore Earth's CO2, in another 1.5 million years, plant life and forests, would start to die off from lack of CO2 which is constantly being absorbed by the Earth and converted into fossil fuels.  Currently, there is only 420 parts per million CO2 in our atmosphere.  That is less than half of 1/10th of 1%.  Our planet is starving for CO2.

Hopefully, more CO2 and more warming will also put off and delay the next coming ice age, or rather, the next glaciation period, which has been a reoccurring cycle, roughly every 100,000 years, which started about 2.5 million years ago. 

Technically, we are still in an ice age.  We are at the tail end of a 10 to 15 thousand year warm period (around 2 dozen global warming events in the last 2.5 million years) in between the 85 to 90 thousand year Glaciation periods.  Glaciation periods, popularly known as ice ages, are devastating to plant life and human life.

Canada, New York, and Northern Europe, used to be under 2 miles thick of ice.  Vast forests were destroyed.  Whatever wasn't iced over by the massive northern glaciers, died off from the cold temperatures.

Hopefully more CO2 and more warmth will save the forests, plant life, animal life, and mankind for awhile longer by delaying the next "ice age".

text:
Grey goo, a nightmarish scenario of nanotechnology in which out-of-control self-replicating nanobots destroy the biosphere by endlessly producing replicas of themselves and feeding on materials necessary for life. The term was coined by American engineer Eric Drexler in his book Engines of Creation (1986). Molecular electronics‚Äîa subfield of nanotechnology where individual molecules can become circuit elements‚Äîwould make it possible to manipulate matter at the molecular and atomic level, and this, combined with advances in the physical sciences and gene technology, would make it possible for enormous transformative power to be unleashed.

Optimists have hailed the positive possibilities of such self-replicating machines. Molecular-level ‚Äúassemblers‚Äù could solve the world‚Äôs energy crisis through low-cost solar power, cure terrible diseases like cancer by boosting the human immune system, completely clean up the environment, and even enable the restoration of extinct species. The cheapness and abundance of materials, since the basic building blocks of the technology are at the molecular level, would make it easy and cheap to create any product, including incredibly inexpensive pocket supercomputers.

However, pessimists have warned against the possibility of such molecular-level assemblers wreaking havoc because they could spin out of control, could be deliberately diverted to destructive applications, or become so incredibly efficient and intelligent that human oversight or control would become superfluous. Central to this argument is that nanotechnology crucially gives nanoassemblers the ability to reproduce, meaning that it would be a small step from an intelligent robot to a robot species. Moreover, historical examples of unforeseen consequences of technological innovation, such as the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria or DDT-resistant malarial mosquitoes, have been used to underline the dangers of creating robots, engineered organisms, and nanobots that self-replicate, manifestly multiplying their capacity for destruction of the physical world.

text:
Let's say for arguments sake that all global warming alarmists are correct and the ice caps are going to melt. Top ecologists like Patrick Moore, one of the founders of Greenpeace, have stated that warmer temperatures and higher CO2 levels are conducive to the further greening of the earth. Plants would thrive and the deserts would recede. Plants thrive at 1100 to 2000 ppm Co2 in the atmosphere. The current average is 400 ppm. A tree consumes 2000 gallons on average per year.
 You also would gain agricultural land were there is now tundra and permafrost if the earth warms. So, you can't predict that there would be a net loss of habitat. You would also increase the evaporation cycle so there would be more water vapor  held in the atmosphere at any given time and in places that currently get very little rainfall.

All these things aside, if you're reading this, let's conduct a basic science experiment. Go fill up a glass of ice water and let the ice melt. Please reply back to this comment and let me know when the glass over flows.

Stop giving charlatans the emotional response they are prompting from you!

text:
It would be interesting to know what happened in the Arctic during the 10,800 BCE abrupt climate change. We know there were two ice sheets - smaller Cordilleran and bigger Laurentide on North America. The Laurentide perhaps 3 - 4 km thick at some places. 

There was a paper published in Feb 2018 in The Journal of Geology about extraordinary biomass burning around 10,800 BCE. It is fascinating.

Adjusted quote: "Around 10,800 BCE, likely within the span of 21 years between 10,818 BCE and 10,797 BCE, ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 (area as big as the US), burned. The concentrations of soot, used to estimate the global amount of biomass burned, suggest that wildfires around 10,800 BCE consumed considerably more biomass than during the K-Pg extinction event."

If interested the links are https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695703?journalCode=jg for part 1 and https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/695704 for part 2. 

It would be interesting to calculate how much CO2 must have been released when ‚àº9% of world terrestrial biomass on ‚àº10 million km2 burned. The wildfires on 70,000 km¬≤ in Australia this year are estimated to release about 900 million tons of CO2, which equals to double the country's total yearly fossil fuel emissions."

Perhaps CO2 released by burning of ‚àº9% of Earth's terrestrial biomass, on ‚àº10 million km2 might have contributed to melting of Cordilleran and Laurentide ice sheets? At present CO2 melts ice in Arctic, Greenlad, Antarctica so we can assume it should have been melting ice also around 10,800 BCE as well. 

There is a puzzling energy paradox. Melting of ice sheets happened during very cold period, so it should not have happened.

What mechanisms or combination of might have caused rapid melting of several kilometres thick ice sheets?

One simple physics principle is that the weight of several millions cubic kilometres of ice pushes the continent down. Heavy ice depresses the surface, at times pushing it below sea level, making the ice sheets to get in contact with warmer ocean, causing the ice sheets to retreat and stabilizing the system. Destabilize the system enough with a powerful external factor and things start moving quickly. 

Recent scientific papers start to provide more and more evidence that an external fast acting factor was in effect around 10,800 BCE. 

The paper published in March 2020 in Nature provides evidence of cosmic impact at Syria, coeval with impacts that deposited high-temperature meltglass, melted microspherules, and/or platinum at >50 sites on four continents around 10,800 BCE. Link to the article https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w

Impact on several kilometres thick ice sheet in Canada would not have left a permanent crater imprinted in the ground but more likely a depression filled with water which today would be in the form of a lake. 

There are several candidates for comet fragments impacts on ice sheet in Canada around 10,800 BCE. One of them possibly in Great Lakes area, perhaps the Saginaw Bay, Michigan // Lake Nippon // Manicouagan Reservoir // Gulf of Saint Lawrence // 

It is suggested it started in direction from Western coast to Eastern coast. 

It would be interesting to check the known impact craters in the world for a possible "string impacts. Just a few candidates - Rochechouart crater in France, Saint Martin crater in Manitoba, Obolon crater in Ukraine, Red Wing crater in North Dakota. If there is any researcher or enthusiast out there able to get some funding go for it.:-)

If you have not seen a string impact video please check the well-known Shoemaker‚ÄìLevy 9 string impacts on Jupiter in July 1994 on BBC Studios YouTube channel https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DgOTcIfU75Y

As mentioned in the March 2020 paper in Nature (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-60867-w) there might have been multiple airbursts/impacts across at least four continents. These are proposed to have resulted from a one of a series of short-period, active comets known to break up frequently and to shed dozens to thousands of fragments that are 10 to 1000‚Äâm‚Äâin diameter, each capable of producing catastrophic airburst/impacts. The largest cometary debris clusters are proposed to be capable of causing thousands of airbursts within a span of minutes across one entire hemisphere of Earth. An encounter with such a million-km-wide debris cluster would be thousands of times more probable than a collision with a 100-km-wide comet or a 10-km asteroid.

If I owned a water front home on a permanent foundation, that I paid a LOT of money for, then some homes appeared in front of my home, corrugated cardboard homes, that caused my yard to flood(?)  I'm sure I would be more than angry.
So rising sea levels:  the floating homes are safe but the permanent structures are left to suffer the effects caused by hollow cement tubes that "displace A Lot of water"? 

A few floating homes here or there would make an unnoticable difference, but what happens when you build urban sprawl?  Who's making the concerns of rising seas levels more immediate?
Just a thought.

text: Very anthropocentric and unrealistic. Sure, adaptation is probably better than mitigation, but this doesn't address the root cause of the problem, which is burgeoning population growth. Building on water is definitely not a sustainable and cost-effective solution for everyone, nor is it going to enhance the natural ecosystem services that our marine environment is providing us. Our oceans act as a buffer by absorbing excess heat and CO2, which has shielded humans from even more rapid¬†and adverse impacts of¬†climate shifts. By taking developments to the sea, it might only alter the marine¬†geochemistry and make situations worse than before. Humans need to stop being too ambitious and idealistic. I might think that even climate refugees would want to stay in their own country owing to the sense of belonging they have to their land (please watch the Kiribati documentary) and protect it by planting mangroves/building coral seawalls(nature-based solutions) rather than migrating to live on what these architects may think as "great homes".

text:
Aaaaagh, this documentary is soooo uninformed. The "experts" presented should be ashamed of themselves. Their myopic vision of global warming is infantile .... really !
Let's get is straight, global warming is a very real and very dangerous issue. But will not cause rising sea levels. Even when it gets warm enough for the poles to melt. However, and this is a huge however, what will come will be worse.
You see, when the average temperature rises it is true that ice melts. That is kindergarten science. But something else happens simultaneously. A massive increase in evaporation. And it turns out that the effect caused by melting, is more or less equalised by the loss of ocean water by evaporation for every degree rise in temperature. So everything is OK, the ocean levels do not rise significantly. Well, not exactly.
Ocean evaporation happens naturally all the time, even today. We call the phenomenon clouds. And when the clouds get heavy enough another phenomenon happens. We call it rain, or precipitation. It also has the effect of destabilising the equilibrium of the atmosphere, which causes yet another phenomenon, we call that wind.
Today, when the oceans warm up significantly during the summer, all of these phenomenon combine, and are regularly observed. This causes a tropical storm, or in extremis hurricanes. A hurricane is determined by extremely high winds, atmospheric distortion, and massive amounts of rain.
Hence, rising temperatures will not cause the oceans to rise, but a massive increase in rainfall globally, causing flooding in inland as well as coastal areas. And if you happen to live in an inland city that lies in a terrestrial depression, it will be worse of all, as the rainfall will be significantly higher than the lands ability to disperse it. You certainly will not want to be living anywhere near a river or lake, or a delta. And unfortunately for us, in our development as species, that is exactly where we have congregated, and built towns and cities.
And once the rainfall has sustained enough for the land to become waterlogged, a catastrophe unfolds, everywhere. Which absolutely confirms, the irrational but scientifically endorsed events on earth 9000 years ago, as recorded in the worlds most popular book.

text:
Using simple math, it will take more than 14000 years to melt the Greenland ice sheet (aka Arctic polar cap).
Data from Wikipedia (they claim reliable sources like NASA, etc.). The total mass of Greenland's ice sheet is a stunning 2.85 million cubic kilometers. The melting is between 195 and 239 cubic kilometers per year (referring to two different studies). This means that to melt it all will take (2850000/200) 14250 years -- using 200 km3/year. Also according to Wikipedia, this will cause the sea level to rise with 7.2 meters. This will equal to (720 cm/14250) 0,5 mm per year, or 5 cm in 100 years (2120 AD).
This should hardly be a cause for alarmism, and it leaves us with plenty of time, a century, to adjust to the 5 cm rise in sea level, which involves taking a tiny step back.

text: Hi: I compare man Gray goo (also spelled grey goo) is a hypothetical global catastrophic scenario involving molecular nanotechnology in which out-of-control self-replicating machines consume all biomass on Earth while building more of themselves, a scenario that has been called ecophagy("eating the environment", more literally "eating the habitation"). The original idea assumed machines were designed to have this capability, while popularizations have assumed that machines might somehow gain this capability by ac..
author: Li Joso

text:
Grey goo, a nightmarish scenario of nanotechnology in which out-of-control self-replicating nanobots destroy the biosphere by endlessly producing replicas of themselves and feeding on materials necessary for life. The term was coined by American engineer Eric Drexler in his book Engines of Creation (1986). Molecular electronics‚Äîa subfield of nanotechnology where individual molecules can become circuit elements‚Äîwould make it possible to manipulate matter at the molecular and atomic level, and this, combined with advances in the physical sciences and gene technology, would make it possible for enormous transformative power to be unleashed.

Optimists have hailed the positive possibilities of such self-replicating machines. Molecular-level ‚Äúassemblers‚Äù could solve the world‚Äôs energy crisis through low-cost solar power, cure terrible diseases like cancer by boosting the human immune system, completely clean up the environment, and even enable the restoration of extinct species. The cheapness and abundance of materials, since the basic building blocks of the technology are at the molecular level, would make it easy and cheap to create any product, including incredibly inexpensive pocket supercomputers.

However, pessimists have warned against the possibility of such molecular-level assemblers wreaking havoc because they could spin out of control, could be deliberately diverted to destructive applications, or become so incredibly efficient and intelligent that human oversight or control would become superfluous. Central to this argument is that nanotechnology crucially gives nanoassemblers the ability to reproduce, meaning that it would be a small step from an intelligent robot to a robot species. Moreover, historical examples of unforeseen consequences of technological innovation, such as the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria or DDT-resistant malarial mosquitoes, have been used to underline the dangers of creating robots, engineered organisms, and nanobots that self-replicate, manifestly multiplying their capacity for destruction of the physical world.

I can nearly guarantee by the time I am 85 if not sooner, this world will be close to uninhabitable.

text:
How To Reduce Pollution

1. Many Production Companies Has To Be Stopped

From global warming or climate change there is going to be mass extinctions of humans and wildlife, we do not know when, but from pollution also we are going to face mass extinction.
We manufacture so many products and it is creating pollution and pollution has increased to such an extent that it has become a threat to the world. So if we minimise our products, pollution would be less.
We produce so many things which we do not need as a necessity, like cold drinks, leather products, potato wafers, chips, fruit juices, chocolates, biscuits, pickles, ice creams, etc. 
Cold drinks, fruit juices, chocolates, biscuits, pickles, ice creams, etc. should be cooked at home only. Instead of cold drinks people should drink natural drinks such as lime water, coconut water or just any fruit, not any fruit juice, just the whole fruit which can be served when a customer comes in a shop, hotel or a person selling this drinks on a street and serve it to him. If we stopped producing this things which are not required as a necessity for humans, so much pollution could be reduced.
What about the companies that are going to be shut down. They would have debts to pay, just excuse them.
If we colour the clothes pollution occurs. So if we don't colour our clothes, the pollution resulting from colouring the clothes can be stopped. Let everything remain in white natural colour. 

2. We Should Cook Foods In Its Natural Form

We can cook rice and wheat in our homes and eat it. Rice and Wheat is produced in farms. Then it is packed and transported to big warehouses, then wholesalers buy from them and supply to retail shops. 
But if a manufacturing company makes bread from rice and wheat, then to make bread a manufacturing company has to be set up, machines and working staffs are needed. When a company is built many other things are also needed. Then at last a plastic pack is required to pack the breads.
So if we start cooking eatable things in its natural form then we do not need many companies like bread manufacturing company, tomato ketchup, noodles, fruit jam, pizza, burger, etc., the things required for the company and the plastic pack, paper box pack and glass bottles. If done like this, so many companies will not be required and hence less pollution for the world. Humans have to do this before it is too late.

If this is done, then many jobs would be lost. For that many peoples should do farming and they should be given loans if they do not have enough money to start farming on their own. Please don't think farming as a low work. Many people should study botany subject so that they have knowledge of plants and they should do farming.
Is their any another solution, that humans won't lose jobs and also planet earth will be saved.
Industrial jobs or planet earth, which should we save, planet earth is more important. Humans have to take this step certainly instead of going on polluting the earth, making wildlife extinct and also mass extinctions of humans after 100 or 200 years. Humans should not want this to happen.

text: I was in Southern Italy last year and was fortunate enough to take a lovely tour of the coastline near Naples. I was immediately struck by the difference in tidal levels there and the tidal levels in my native Ireland. Also the infrastucture in towns is built right up to the edge of the sea, no taking into account storms, large sea rises and surges and things you have to take into account on Ireland coasts. Irelands tides can vary by many meters while those in Italy seemed to vary by less than 30cm. I would imagine the sea conditions in Portugal would be very similar to that of Ireland, high tidal ranges and stormy conditions. The Atlantic is a tough Ocean to deal with.

text: The problem you have is the linking of precise land areas to home ownership over many generations. This makes location inflexible and not amenable to change with changing climatic conditions. The idea of floating real estate is attractive but needs an enormous system of artificial infrastructures constantly manned and monitored. No more foreign holidays for owners of floating homes unless they can hire a very trustworthy person to watch over their home and prevent sinking and flooding. Land based houses on high land do not have this problem. Like apartments the owners of floating homes will have high maintenance fees which will need to be paid throughout all their lives, for many people adequate pension provision or lifelong working into old age will become essential, not possible for many present day people unless the government moves to protect job security and ensure pension income for all. This is not done now.

text: Over time that might lead to the creation of complete submerged metropolises which may be something they want to avoid, I don't see it as being any more radical then having a floating buoyant city, other than cost perhapse. However I think you lose too much connection to the original location when you end up floating above it.... Better to build on top to keep the sence of geographical connection otherwise people won't recognise where they are from especially if you build it to change all the time. Don't get me wrong it is a elegant solution though people's sense of nationality and location can be just as big a problem. Also the problem with water is it is so level and perfectly flat, it might look different from the inside with multiple levels integrated into the larger structures, its just that from the outside it all looks so flat and the different levels and natural dips and rises in land is far more romantic, interesting and varied in my opinion.

Lets just say that there is enough towns and cities to house all of the homeless, the only problem is that there is a number of homeless that wouldnt want to leave their homeless status for their own reasons, then we have to take into account that the buildings in these places are not up to the structural code that is in place in each country, also ther is the fact that many of these arent connected by modern day roads, or maybe no road ot path at all, as they have been abbandoned for so long that thye are no longer on the map so to say. 

So, yes, your idea is a good one, yet there are a lot of factors involved, the updating of the towns and cities, the remapping of the world and the relocation of people would cost millions, posibbly billions, no matter the country your in. But if people would find a way to bring these places back to life that would be better than to spend aproximately the same amout of money to build things from brand new. Yes, money would still be spent, but at least the money would be spent bringing back old towns and cities that have spent a long time forgotten or lost, even soeme times both. 

In the end: good idea that countries should take on board and find a way to bring into reality.

text:
¬†@Warau Kyuuketsuki¬†  The materials you are talking about range from expensive to nosebleedingly expensive. Galvanic corrosion is a big deal in the ocean and anything with aluminum in it is very susceptible to galvanic corrosion since it is so high up on the periodic table. Titanium is almost inert in seawater but it's not only very expensive but really hard to work with (watch a video on building the SR71).  Don't even think about Monel or Hastelroy unless you have a defense department budget. Schedule 316 Stainless is fairly cheap and quiet good in marine environments but as soon as you get it underwater in a low 02 condition it will corrode just the same as regular steel. Concretes are great in compression but are useless in tension so you have to reinforce them with something. I remember the ferrocrete craze in the 80's and that was a clusterfuck of epic proportions. There could be a case made for 3d printing waste plastics and forming habitats with that. Then actually encouraging organic encroachment and turning your home into a reef. Then below water windows could have robotic wipers that clean off critters that want to attach to the glass. Oddly enough marine life loves attaching to glass what with it being all smooth and hard. You are not going to build those gleaming white pleasure domes in an oceanic environment without a lot of expensive maintenance. Take it from a long time sailboat owner who loves the ocean. Sorry this is so long but this a pet subject of mine.

Oh, and don't even get me started on electrical systems.

text:
¬†@alex carter¬† But only if the construction of the house doesn't give the strong winds (like they're getting more and more frequent these days thanks to Climate Change, too) too much surface to push the construction over - and THAT has not been addressed by anyone in particular of the "floating house(boat)" architects in the whole show.

I think the construction of the French Architect looks most  sturdy though since it seems to have a lot of under-water area and is constructed quite aerodynamically. But the others looked pretty "meh" in terms of storm(surge) contingency strategies. And the higher a house(boat), the broader and deeper it needs to have a "rooting" in the water to not be able to be "toppled over" or even to the side.

And there were a lot of constructions shown, that didn't look very "aerodynamic", so force of air moving (wind) against their flat surfaces would meet maximum resistance - which translates into kinetic energy, that could move the construction one way or another, depending on the rest of its design.

But the overall "security concepts for floating Housing" was missing entirely in the Documentary. A few minutes before the end, when floods and catastrophes were mentioned, I was thinking "Oh, now they finally get to it.", but: they didn't. So, without very realistic concepts implemented into these ideas, I will just "smile and wave (goodbye)" at them. Utopian Designs can be inspiring, but they need to be tested and refined with REALISTIC conditions, challenges and threats and then be adapted accordingly - which is why I favor the French Architect most, too, since he kinda mentions, that he also is aware of pragmatic steps of adapting his aesthetic ideas to pragmatic circumstances/conditions.

So, I wonder, if there is an extra documentary about safety of these floating constructions?

text:
Currently such a house costs about ‚Ç¨500,000 to ‚Ç¨600,000 in Rotterdam (The Netherlands).
However, the currently ordered houses are prognosed to cost about ‚Ç¨400,000 for similar more efficiently build houses.
The company building these specific houses for the Rotterdam area is striving to build these type of houses for about ‚Ç¨200,000 in the forseeable future. Which is possible only when this industry is scaled up.

Comparable traditional "land" houses currently costs about ‚Ç¨300,000 (and up) in Rotterdam. While a relatively moderate appartment costs about ‚Ç¨200,000 (and up) in Rotterdam. Note: Upperclass housing in Rotterdam is far more expensive. ‚Ç¨600,000 and up for an upperclass house is not uncommon in Rotterdam (or Amsterdam).
Note: You can find cheaper housing in Rotterdam. But a) not by much and b) either very small or of low living quality.

To my knowledge, no taxpayer money is invested in building these houses. I do not exclude that some taxpayer money is invested in innovative solutions of which the design of waterbased housing is one of them. This money usually goes to universities or other nonprofit organisations.

Concluding (with respect to The Netherlands): 
Yes. It is currently more expensive. But the expenses are going down each year. It is not that much more expensive (or even cheaper) when compared to the upperclass housing in (for instance) Rotterdam or Amsterdam. And no, no taxpayer money is wasted to serve the elite. At least, not in The Netherlands.

text:
Using simple math, it will take more than 14000 years.
Data from Wikipedia (they claim reliable sources like NASA, etc.). The total mass of Greenland's ice sheet is a stunning 2.85 million cubic kilometers. The melting is between 195 and 239 cubic kilometers per year (referring to two different studies). This means that to melt it all will take (2850000/200) 14250 years -- using 200 km3/year. Also according to Wikipedia, this will cause the sea level to rise with 7.2 meters. This will equal to (720 cm/14250) 0,5 mm per year, or 5 cm in 100 years (2120 AD).
This should hardly be a cause for alarmism, and it leaves us with plenty of time, a century, to adjust to the 5 cm rise in sea level, which involves taking a tiny step back.
